div.p: SAGUM, in Roman antiquity, a military habit, open from top to bottom, and uſually faſtened on the right ſhoulder with a buckle or claſp. It was not different in ſhape from the chlamys of the Greeks and the paludamentum of the generals. The only difference between them was, that the paludamentum was made of a richer fluff, was generally of a purple colour, and both longer and fuller than the ſagum.
